name: TYC 3318-01333-1
scenarioDescription:
The TYC 3318-01333-1 Exoplanetary System

TYC 3318-01333-1 is a star with 1.19 times the mass of the Sun, and 5.9 times its radius. It is located 1622.33 light years away from the solar system.

TYC 3318-01333-1 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

TYC 3318-01333-1 b

TYC 3318-01333-1 b was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.41 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 562.00 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, TYC 3318-01333-1.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.098, which means that when TYC 3318-01333-1 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 1.28 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 1.55. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of TYC 3318-01333-1 b is 1086.91 times the mass of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, TYC 3318-01333-1 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system TYC 3318-01333-1, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Multiple Observatories.
